comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06/7169689176/in/photostream]

for Dainty Lingerie no less!! Carol

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Based on the fact that it's on a junction, and the ground slopes steeply right to left, I'm going to guess that this shop is at 12 Broad Street. If so, the shop is long gone, replaced by an ugly cubic thing.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: I would say that the local Horrockses sales, marketing and merchantising team paid for this photograph. They probably won the annual marketing prize for their efforts here!!

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: They were a right crowd of Horrockes and thats for sure.  What a wonderful shot, not only of the gentleman and his infant son in whom he has such pride but of the display and variety he has in his shop and windows.  Blasts from the past - gingham, voile, overalls, flannelettes - this one has it all including the picture on display of the old lady with the loom.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I know! The only thing missing is Winceyette... Or is it? Screwing in monocle, and having another look!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: I think that this is the shop on the corner of Barronstrand Street and Arundel Lane now occupied by the National Irish Bank. This shop would be at the top of Barronstrand Street immediately adjacent to Broad Street, hence the location name.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] It's possible, the road has the same slope, and the building has two windows at first floor level like Old Mr. Brennan's.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] That looks like a good fit alright, well done.

comment.author: 75116182@N04
comment._content: Great shot!

comment.author: 63429800@N06
comment._content: What a great shot from the days before chain stores! Some towns were known far and wide for their shops: MacIntyre's of Belmullet, E.J McDermott's of Castlerea, Todd's of Limerick. These days every town has the same dull selection of "household names".

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/paddywhack56/] I miss shops like these, one of my favourite Waterford ones was George Whites in O'Connell street and another was Johnny Hearnes hardware on the Quay, it survived up until fairly recent times, it was an Aladdins cave of nuts, bolts screws & washers.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Oooh-er, Matron, dainty lingerie!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Was being guided by your skill with sloping ground, but now I'm a little confused by yourself and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04]. Can I stick with Broad Street, or would Barronstrand Street be more accurate. Perhaps Poole said Broad Street because that's where the Brennans lived? (although I thought they'd be more likely to live over the shop) This just in! Checked the 1911 census, and at that point John Brennan, draper (from Kilkenny) was single and living as a boarder at Barronstrand Street.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Is Hearne's gone?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] At [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] 's suggestion I took a look further down the hill, and we agree that this is 27 Barronstrand Street, now occupied by the National Irish Bank.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I google Diaphalene and you get a bunch of Chinese translations, and various websites in Chinese... Interesting

comment.author: 63844591@N04
comment._content: Hearne's moved their shop to a commercial unit at Six Cross Roads Business Park, but the Hearne family had an awful tragedy and have ceased trading. The shop on the Quay ( Coal Quay to be exact, at the foot of Conduit Lane) is closed. I seem to recall in my youth that Brennan's shop was a sub post office before it was bought by Kneisel's jewellers and then subsequently by NIB.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04/] Yes very sad about Hearnes, it was a great little business. Johnny Hearnes shop on Streetview

comment.author: 38915126@N06
comment._content: Wonderful image and capture

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Thanks to both of you for Barronstrand Street correction. Description and tags now amended.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/63844591@N04] Really sad to hear about Hearne's. Our childhood holidays were always spent in Woodstown and later Dunmore East, and the weekly expedition into town always involved a rummage in Hearne's...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
